reviewText: QUARANTINE, I'll tell you right here, is better than I would have expected (or hoped).  It provided some genuine "jump-in-your-seat" moments and there is no doubt my heart was racing during much of it.  It is a pure formula film, almost totally unoriginal...yet it also shows that competent execution is so much a part of the success of a film, particularly in a genre like horror.This is another one of those "Point of View" (POV) films, where we see it all, unedited, through the lens of a camera (CLOVERFIELD and DIARY OF THE DEAD being recent examples).  This technique allows for some sloppiness of editing, lighting, and even continuity.  It saves, no doubt, a great deal on a film's budget.  However, it also requires the film to be effective without the use of a musical soundtrack and frequently requires some very lengthy takes, in which a major mistake by an actor or in the realm of special effects would call for an entire scene to be run again from the top.  I'm not suggesting such film techniques are technical marvels...but they have their own requirements that make the difficult.  As much fun as BLAIR WITCH PROJECT was when it came out (we'd not seen a film like it before), the movies that have come since using the POV method have really jumped ahead in terms of what they can do.  CLOVERFIELD, of course, was heavily computer enhanced after filming (unless I'm much mistaken, the monster destroying NYC was not real)...but QUARANTINE is much more down and dirty.  (I also acknowledge that it was a remake of a foreign film entitled REC, which I've read was also very good, even superior, but I have not seen it, so I can only comment on my experience seeing QUARANTINE.)We begin one evening in front of a fire station.  TV reporter Jennifer Carpenter (EXORCISM OF EMILY ROSE and TV's "Dexter"), speaking to the camera, tells us that she's going to be spending a evening riding along with a fire crew.  We see the raw footage she and her photographer put together...joking with the firemen, sliding down the pole, asking silly questions.  We can already picture in our heads what her editing piece will end up like...complete fluff, but making us feel good about the firemen protecting our city.  But then she and her two man fire crew are called to an apartment building because a woman inside is sick.  They rush into this old, run-down building, where two policeman have arrived ahead of them.  They reach the old woman's apartment to find her standing there, foaming at the mouth, breathing heavily and unresponsive to their questions.  And as we expect, in a sudden burst of action, she attacks her rescuers, going for the throat.  Chaos ensues.Then the folks inside the apartment, including the inevitably motley crew of residents, discover that they have been sealed inside the building by a heavily armed CDC crew.  Thus, they have also been sealed inside with an ever growing number of infected "zombies."  (It's not strictly a zombie movie...the "monsters" are sort of combinations of George Romero's zombies and Danny Boyle's "infected" from 28 DAYS LATER.)The movie plays out in a fairly predictable fashion.  You can almost predict the order in which folks will fall victim.  You know where the next attack is coming from.  You want to yell at the characters for doing stupid things.But you are also drawn into the predicament.  Part of this is the POV technique.  It does often make you feel immersed in the action.  The sound editing is excellent as well, whether it's the frightened breathing of the cameraman, the sounds of struggles two stories below or the screams of people standing just out of view.  While we see plenty of attacks, blood, and some gore...there is also a lot that happens off-screen as well...allowing our imaginations to run wild.  For example, in one scene, an unfortunate resident comes up in an elevator.  As he prepares to step out, a "zombie" dog rushes at him and begins to attack.  The man falls back into the elevator and the dog follows.  The doors close, and those who try to help the man are unable to reopen them.  We hear what's happening behind the door...and I'm sure what we imagine is as savage and bloody as anything the filmmakers would show us.  It's gruesome and unsettling.Overall, the film is well-acted by a bunch of unknown performers.  Most of the performers do a good job of seeming like ordinary guys.  I'm sure much of the dialogue was partially improvised.Let me discuss "star" Jennifer Carpenter in particular, though.  I've read some reviews accusing her of the most atrocious overacting.  Clearly, her performance just didn't work for some folks.  For me, however, she was quite effective.  She gives a performance that towards the end is almost...well, the only word I can come up with is "rococo."  She plays a somewhat vapid but fairly determined reporter, eager to catch everything on film, and frankly, somewhat removed from the reality of what is happening.  Then, after a particularly scary encounter, she is struck with the realization that this is REAL, it is happening to HER and there is a very, very strong chance she will die soon.  She goes into full throttle panic.  Whimpering, jumpy in the extreme, hyper-ventilating, etc.  She shows no bravery, and comes to rely on the pool of light from the video camera as her only connection to sanity and safety.  We are not used to seeing a main character in a film lose such total control over herself.  I don't want to say it is a "daring" performance, but to me, it's what helped to elevate the film beyond the norm.  It does make her somewhat passive in what transpires, because she's such a quivering mound of jello...but it also struck me as somewhat believable.  She seems, frankly, properly traumatized.  And I certainly caught no whiff of giggles from a heavily teen-aged audience.  I think we all  instinctively felt that her pants-wetting terror was a very believable reaction.QUARANTINE is a "cheapie" genre flick...no question.  But it was made with competence, commitment and no hint of irony.  It is scary, fast-moving and involving.  It left me sweating.  If a good, scary thrill is what you're looking for...I can heartily recommend QUARANTINE.  It's nice to say that about a horror film!
summary: A surprisingly effective horror flick.  Gave me a good scare or two.

reviewText: Quarantine (John Erick Dowdle, 2008)Warning: this review contains almost unavoidable spoilers. Skip it if you haven't seen this (or the original, [REC]) yet.The worst thing about Quarantine, John Erick Dowdle's remake of Jaune Balaguero's impressive thriller [REC], has nothing to with the movie itself. While I know I shouldn't judge the movie based on anything but the movie (and, as in the case of all remakes, the original), it really, really annoys me when (and I can't really call this a spoiler) the people who released the film decided to use its final shot in the trailer. Okay, maybe I wouldn't have been nearly as annoyed had I not seen Balaguero's original and known it was the final shot, but I think it's pretty obvious given that scene, and the still from it used on the poster, how this movie is going to end.  There are at least two dozen scenes from the movie that would have worked equally as well. Why blow it for your entire moviegoing audience a month before they get to see the actual movie? That said, however, Quarantine is my favorite foreign-horror remake since The Ring, simply because Dowdle knew not to mess with success; his adaptation isn't quite slavishly faithful (and, like The Ring, the one main added scene actually fits in well with the atmosphere of the rest of the flick), but it's certainly more so than even the foreign-horror remakes we've seen directed by their original directors (yes, Takashi Shimizu, I'm looking at you). And that's topped off by my continued disbelief that Balaguero, whose Darkness was such a godawful mess five or six years ago, was capable of pulling off the original as well as he did. This is a conflation of highly improbables, and they all come together to make a really, really good movie.Jennifer Carpenter (Dexter) plays Angela Vidal, the host of a late-night TV show that, from what we can tell, follows people working a certain job around and shows what they do while the rest of the world is asleep. Tonight, it's firefighters, and she and her cameraman Scott (Heist's Steve Harris) get partnered with Jake (Hostel's Jay Hernandez) and George (Living Hell's Jonathon Schaech). All goes well until the firefighters answer a call to aid a sick woman in a tenement building and find the police already on the scene. No sooner do they discover the woman is a lot more than just sick than everytihng explodes outside, with cops, firefighters, and the National Guard quarantining the building, trapping Angela, Scott, Jake, a badly-wounded George, a cop (Stomp the Yard's Columbus Short) who's already close to the edge, and the rest of the building's inhabitants inside with the sick woman.As is increasingly common these days, the movie is shot purely from the perspective of a single camera (think Document of the Dead, Cloverfield, etc.). It's a trick that's kind of getting old now, but when used correctly, it's still very effective. It's used correctly here. The lack of omniscient cameraman makes for a movie that's simultaneously frustrating and jump-out-of-your-seat shocking on a fairly regular basis (after about fifteen minutes of setup in and around the firehouse); you're never exactly sure what's going on, and the level of detail you do get every once in a while is just enough to keep you straining to make out more. This is bound to turn off some film viewers who are more used to having everything laid out for them, but if you don't mind filling in some blank spots yourself, you'll find a lot to like here. It's that rarest of Hollywood productions, a remake that's almost as good as the film upon which it is based. ***

reviewText: Quarantine spends half the movie setting up the situation for the plot to happen.  Which is a lot to tolerate in a movie that's trying to present itself as psuedo-realism.  Yes, reality can be dull and boring. But do you want to watch that in a movie?A journalist and her cameraman tail a group of firefighter's call into a apartment building. Things go worse as this "rabies-like" disease takes its zombie-like effect.The main go-getter journalist character is not in the slightest believable as a journalist.  Her acting is aweful, frankly.  The rest of the cast is fairly decent.  Its to bad so much of the movie is with her instead.They do all kinds of things which are unconvincing in this movie and it takes a lot to look past its flaws.  Take, for instance, a scene which I did like where the cameraman (in his one "on camera" scene) kills an infected woman:  there's a nice idea for a shot where the camera is recording the bashing of the woman to death.  Its a fun idea really, getting to that realism  (what would you use for a weapon, whatever is in your hand of course!), but the camera shows this as an up and down steady and straight movement.  Even when the camera supposedly hits the woman there's no shake.  Plenty of camera shaking elsewhere in the movie why not here?  The camera pans up to look through a laughably splattered lens. Then the camera man gives us a fairly convincing weep over having killed someone.  Ok, but not great.  Like many things in this movie its just not fully realized.The movie ends when the remaining  few are up in a room where they discover what may have caused all this to happen....except for some unknown reason this part of the movie seems rushed through and not developed.To much of this movie left me unsatisfied.  It wasn't bad, but I probably wouldn't watch it again.

reviewText: I had the opportunity last week to catch Quarantine, the 2008 American "re-do" of 2007's[Rec]. So I said to myself, "why not give the original a look to see if they were on par with each other." And [REC] was worth the look. But why do I call Quarantine a "re-do" instead of a "re-make", you ask? I'll get to that in a minute.{REC} is a very well done Spanish film by Jaume Balagueró & Paco Plaza that kind of combines the idea of Rage virus infected maniacs from28 Days Laterwith the notion that zombies and demonic possession are nothing more than a mutated virus strain. Oh don't worry, I'm not spoiling anything here!I mean really...both movies ultimately offer no better explanation for the origin of what's going on than any of its predecessors. I'd say thatResident Evil& 28 Days Later make the best attempts to suggest origins for why "zombies" are walking the earth, but even those leave the door wide open to prequels or sequels that change the whole idea of "what started it all."So enter [REC} with a somewhat unique explanation (a la videogame-esque recording device found by the characters late in the film) of why zombies haunt this story. Yes...I said "re-do" as opposed to "re-make". A re-make is when a director takes an older film, sometimes even a classic, and makes it better. A re-do is when a director takes a film and adds nothing to the original (and in most cases makes it worse). reviewText: I apologize for the pun above...I couldn't resist, mostly because it's true on both accounts. Firstly, a brief history lesson. Last year, a Spanish film called [rec] came out to much acclaim in Spain. It quickly traveled most of the Western world, building fans and kudos while systematically scaring the wits out of 99% of people who saw it. Since then, it's been out everywehre in the Western world in either theatres or on DVD.Everywhere except the United States.Here, we have Hollywood with the mentality of, "why bring over a perfectly terrifying film when we can remake it in our own language." Consequently, we still don't have [rec] here. But we do have Quarantine. Having seen [rec] and hearing that Quarantine was practically a frame-by-frame remake in some ways, I was curious to see how it'd hold up.Things began well, with a nice set up that involved some good banter back and forth. The trip to the apartment complex and the realization that something horrible is happening works well. Sure, some scenes have been changed for added gore/shock value, but overall it was a good, if needless, remake. Unfortunately, what I like to call the "Marilyn Burns Effect" happens and ruins the last 1/3 of the movie. Horror aficionados will remember Marilyn as the actress in the original Texas Chainsaw Massacre. While many hold this film in high regards (and rightly so), Marilyn spends the last 10-20 minutes of the movie running, arms flailing and screaming her head off. Today, reviewing that film, it comes across more humorous than scary.And unfortunately, that's what happens in Quarantine. Towards the end, you just want to reach through the screen and slap the main character. I could go into a deep discussion of female hysteria in film, especially as it relates to needing a man to calm her down (usually with a slap to the face), but I won't. Needless to say, that stereotype continues in this film, complete with an unsuccessful talking down by her male camera person, and it turns into a self-parody.I usually enjoy Jennifer Carpenter; I liked her in the Exorcism of Emily Rose and the few episodes I've seen of Dexter, but she just ruins any thrills in the last third of Quarantine. This probably won't surprise anyone, but Quarantine felt like a "hipper," "more stylized" version of [rec], minus the themes introduced at the end and without any creativity. Don't get me wrong, Quarantine isn't a horrible film. It does have a couple decent scares. The problem is that whatever it can do, [rec] can do better. The fear in [rec] is palpable simply because it is simplistic in its presentation. It's a much scarier film. [rec] is, in fact, on my short list of films that have scared me. Quarantine just doesn't cut it. My recommendation is let your wallet do the talking and skip Quarantine for the much superior and terrifying [rec].

reviewText: [Rec](2007) was an award winning Spanish horror thriller with a unique perspective, as the premise was that the entire movie consisted of video shot by a television crew, as they followed the activities of a fire department unit, and are swept into a strange and horrific situation.  With a few additional elements, Quarantine (2008) is basically a remake of [REC], with the setting moved from Spain to Los Angeles, with English replacing Spanish as the spoken language.  This review with compare the two films, and will assume the reader is familiar with REC, and contain some major spoilers.  So proceed as your own risk.Quarantine does a very good job of taking [REC]'s basic "real-time" approach to filmmaking, and duplicating it technically.  About 10 minutes longer than [REC], Quarantine introduces some new wrinkles into the basic story, changes some names and other details, but almost all of the significant elements of REC, are included in Quarantine.  Interestingly, in the making of featurette on the DVD, those involved with Quarantine do not mention [REC] by name, or even acknowledges it as a source.  John Erick Dowdle (Devil, The Poughkeepsie Tapes) and Drew Dowdle, receive writing credit for Quarantine, which was essentially adapted almost entirely from [REC], which was co-written by Luiso Berdejo, Jaume Balaguero, and Paco Plaza.  In their commentary for the film, the Dowdle's to their best to avoid mentioning [REC].The heroine of both films is TV host named Angela Vidal, with Jennifer Carpenter (Dexter) assuming the role in Quarantine, originally played by Manuela Velasco in [REC].  Accompanied by her camera operator Scott Percival (Steve Harris), Vidal is at a LA fire station shooting a piece about firemen, when a call comes in and they join the unit on a call.  They enter a three storey apartment building, and together with two policemen, break into a unit where an old woman is apparently ill.  Behaving strangely, the woman bites one of the cops in the neck.  The group retreats downstairs, and discovers that the building has been locked down, and that the authorities will use force to prevent anyone from leaving.  Trapped inside with victims of a strange disease, the survivors' numbers dwindle, and hope begins to fade.One of the most significant changes in Quarantine, involves the abandonment of a religious element, and changing the cause of the "infection" to something similar to rabies.  A character with veterinary training recognizes the symptoms of the disease, and later tests of brain matter are attempted.Other changes result in increasing the level of action.  A dog named Max was mentioned in [REC], as a carrier of the disease, but was never seen.  In Quarantine, Max appears as a large ferocious dog, and the film also features an elevator that was not present in [REC], where several tense scenes occur.  Another incident features camera operator Scott Percival, bashing one of the infected to death with his camera, and when a survivor opens a window and exposes himself, he is shot by a sniper.Like [REC], Quarantine starts innocuously, and then suddenly plunges into a dark world of uncertainly and immense danger.  The building becomes a prison, where those inside become infected, and join a bloodthirsty hoard.  As the intensity of the violence increases, the setting becomes darker as electrical power is cut.  Soon the light mounted to the camera, becomes the sole source of illumination.  And when that is gone, the camera's infrared viewer provides the film's final haunting images.It isn't believable that a cameraman would continue to shoot, when people are being attacked, or when he is running for his life, however when you are caught up in the panic of what seems like a real event, it becomes easier to make allowances for questionable "reality".  Steve Harris has a more prominent role than the camera operator in [REC], and is a more active contributor.  Angela Vidal is more assertive in Quarantine, but the character isn't as believable or convincing as in [REC].  Jennifer Carpenter no doubt studied and learned from Manuela Velasco's performance.  Her performance isn't bad, it just lacks the intensity and realism of Velasco's.With [REC] providing a terrific example, Quarantine delivers a higher level of action, and although the characters and tone are a little different, the central thrust is much the same.  While both films are very similar and worth seeing, REC would be the one to see first.  It's unfortunate that those connected with Quarantine appear to be reluctant to acknowledge the debt owed to REC.  The Dowdle's did write a sequel,Quarantine 2: Terminal(2010), which does not follow in the footsteps of [REC]'s sequel[REC] 2(2009).
summary: a solid remake of a [REC], with a few embellishments...

reviewText: Though I enjoyed watching the film itself, I must say that except the POV camera theme that is a new trend in horror films, "Quarantine" offers nothing new. The setting is familiar - it is about a group of people trapped in an old LA apartment building. Malevolent forces that attack them come from inside the building, not from the outside, and the terrifying consequences are told from a viewpoint of a TV reporter Angela (Jennifer Carpenter).Though the images are spooky and acting is pretty strong (with so much screaming from Jennifer Carpenter, a scream queen of the new generation), the story gets weak as the film goes on. Characters repeat the same mistakes, often so incredibly careless when they should be cautious about approaching someone who is obviously "infected.""Quarantine" is a Hollywood remake of the Spanish chiller "[REC]," which I think is a little overrated. For me, the "Blair Witch"-like shaky handheld camera is not the best way to scare the audiences. The first-person camera effectively provides a realistic documentary touch at first, but the narrative gimmick soon becomes artificial and tedious as in "Cloverfield." If you are being chased by monsters or zombies, carrying around a camera with you is the last thing you would do.For anyone who has seen the original, the new version directed by John Erick Dowdle may look like an almost exact duplicate. The new version has become longer and the setting is now in Los Angles, but what happens inside the dark apartment building remains the same. If you have seen the original Spanish film, you have seen "Quarantine.""Quarantine" is not as bad as some of the negative reviews might lead you to believe. It is only that jaded horror fans, me included, are hard to be impressed. The film is entertaining to some degree, but in spite of (or because of) its documentary-like shooting style it requires a considerable amount of suspension of disbelief.
summary: "Blair Witch Project -- 28 Days Later" Average Horror with a POV Camera
